p.01703376c4a81c0e9d91: Remove an item from the json by path
p.01703376c4a81c0e9d92:
Use [Remove From JSON](/#editedItem=017fb761ae7674ea17de) instead.

Reason:
- doesn't expect source to be json object, but json string only
- path doesn't support jsonpath-plus features
- returns json string, instead of json object
***
Removes an element from a JSON string specified by the property path.

The path is specified in dotted form. To remove an element inside an array, the property needs to be included inside brackets, e.g. '[name]'.


**Examples**:
```
RemoveElementFromJSON({ "a": { "b": "hello"}, "c": "coucou" }, 'a.b') -> { "a": { }, "c": "coucou" }

RemoveElementFromJSON({ "a": [ { "b": "hello", c: "boo 1" }, { "b": "coucou" , c: "boo 2"  } ] }, 'a.[b]') -> { "a": [ { c: "boo 1" }, { c: "boo 2"  } ] }

RemoveElementFromJSON([{ "name" : "House", "doors" : 2 } ,  { "name" : "House", "doors" : 4 }], [name] ) -> [ {"doors": 2} ,  { "doors": 4 } ]
```

If path was not found the result would be null and Error Flow would be triggered.

The brick doesn't support removing from nested arrays, e.g. a.[b].[c].
The initial JSON string to remove from
